title: Nikkō
text:
is a <a href="Cities%20of%20Japan">city</a> located in <a href="Tochigi%20Prefecture">Tochigi Prefecture</a>, <a href="Japan">Japan</a>. , the city had an estimated <a href="population">population</a> of 80,239 in 36,531 households, and a <a href="population%20density">population density</a> of 55 persons per km2. The total area of the city is . It is a popular destination for Japanese and international tourists. Attractions include the <a href="mausoleum">mausoleum</a> of "<a href="sh%C5%8Dgun">shōgun</a>" <a href="Tokugawa%20Ieyasu">Tokugawa Ieyasu</a> (<a href="Nikk%C5%8D%20T%C5%8Dsh%C5%8D-g%C5%AB">Nikkō Tōshō-gū</a>) and that of his grandson <a href="Tokugawa%20Iemitsu">Iemitsu</a> (Iemitsu-byō Taiyū-in), and the <a href="Futarasan%20Shrine">Futarasan Shrine</a>, which dates to the year 767 AD. There are also many famous hot springs ("<a href="onsen">onsen</a>") in the area. Elevations range from 200 to 2,000 meters. The Japanese saying 【日光を見ずして結構と言うなかれ】 "Never say 'kekkō' until you've seen Nikkō"—"kekkō" meaning beautiful, magnificent or "I am satisfied"—is a reflection of the beauty and sites in Nikkō.
Geography.
Nikkō covers a vast area (1,449.83 km2) of rural northwestern Tochigi approximately 140 km north of <a href="Tokyo">Tokyo</a> and 35 km west of <a href="Utsunomiya%2C%20Tochigi">Utsunomiya</a>, the capital of <a href="Tochigi%20Prefecture">Tochigi Prefecture</a>. It is the third-largest city (by area) in Japan, behind <a href="Takayama%2C%20Gifu">Takayama</a> and <a href="Hamamatsu%2C%20Shizuoka">Hamamatsu</a>.
Both the <a href="Watarase%20River">Watarase River</a> and the <a href="Kinugawa%20River">Kinugawa River</a> pass through the city. <a href="Lake%20Ch%C5%ABzenji">Lake Chūzenji</a> and the <a href="Kegon%20Falls">Kegon Falls</a> lie in Nikkō, as does the <a href="Nikko%20Botanical%20Garden">Nikko Botanical Garden</a>. The city's many mountains and waterfalls have made it an important source of <a href="hydroelectric%20power">hydroelectric power</a>. The area has also been used for mining <a href="copper">copper</a>, <a href="aluminum">aluminum</a> and <a href="concrete">concrete</a>.
The weather in Nikkō is fairly similar to that of the northern island of <a href="Hokkaid%C5%8D">Hokkaidō</a>, even though Nikkō is much closer to <a href="Tokyo">Tokyo</a> than Hokkaidō. The elevation of Nikkō plays an important role in this fact. It will usually get cooler as one ascends the mountain. The average temperature of Nikkō is around 7 °C (44 °F) with the warmest months reaching only about 22 °C (72 °F) and the coldest reaching down to about −8 °C (17 °F).

Climate.
Nasu has a <a href="Humid%20continental%20climate">Humid continental climate</a> (Köppen "Cfa") characterized by warm summers and cold winters with heavy snowfall. The average annual temperature in Nasu is 11.6 °C. The average annual rainfall is 1670 mm with September as the wettest month. The temperatures are highest on average in August, at around 23.9 °C, and lowest in January, at around -0.1 °C.
Demographics.
Per Japanese census data, the population of Nikkō has declined over the past 20 years.
History.
 established the temple of <a href="Rinn%C5%8D-ji">Rinnō-ji</a> in 766, followed by the temple of in 784. The village of Nikkō developed around these temples. The shrine of <a href="Nikk%C5%8D%20T%C5%8Dsh%C5%8D-g%C5%AB">Nikkō Tōshō-gū</a> was completed in 1617 and became a major draw of visitors to the area during the <a href="Edo%20period">Edo period</a>. It is known as the burial place of the "<a href="sh%C5%8Dgun">shōgun</a>" <a href="Tokugawa%20Ieyasu">Tokugawa Ieyasu</a>. A number of new roads were built during this time to provide easier access to Nikkō from surrounding regions. Nikkō Tōshō-gū, <a href="Futarasan%20Shrine">Futarasan Shrine</a>, and <a href="Rinn%C5%8D-ji">Rinnō-ji</a> now form the <a href="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="World%20Heritage%20Site">World Heritage Site</a> "<a href="Shrines%20and%20Temples%20of%20Nikk%C5%8D">Shrines and Temples of Nikkō</a>".
During the <a href="Meiji%20period">Meiji period</a>, Nikkō developed as a mountain resort, and became particularly popular among foreign visitors to Japan. The <a href="Japanese%20National%20Railways">Japanese National Railways</a> began service to Nikkō in 1890 with the <a href="Nikk%C5%8D%20Line">Nikkō Line</a>, followed by <a href="Tobu%20Railway">Tobu Railway</a> in 1929 with its <a href="T%C5%8Dbu%20Nikk%C5%8D%20Line">Nikkō Line</a>.
Nikkō was incorporated as a town in 1889 (part of <a href="Kamitsuga%20District%2C%20Tochigi">Kamitsuga District</a>) with the establishment of the modern municipalities system. It was upgraded to city status in 1954 after merging with the neighboring village of <a href="Okorogawa%2C%20Tochigi">Okorogawa</a>.
On March 20, 2006, Nikkō absorbed the neighboring city of <a href="Imaichi%2C%20Tochigi">Imaichi</a>, the town of <a href="Ashio%2C%20Tochigi">Ashio</a> (from <a href="Kamitsuga%20District%2C%20Tochigi">Kamitsuga District</a>), the town of <a href="Fujihara%2C%20Tochigi">Fujihara</a>, and the village of <a href="Kuriyama%2C%20Tochigi">Kuriyama</a> (both from <a href="Shioya%20District%2C%20Tochigi">Shioya District</a>), to create what is officially the new and expanded city of Nikkō. The new city hall is located at the former Imaichi City Hall; the former Nikkō City Hall is now known as Nikkō City Hall-Nikkō Satellite Office.
Government.
Nikkō has a <a href="mayor-council">mayor-council</a> form of government with a directly elected mayor and a <a href="unicameral">unicameral</a> city legislature of 24 members. Nikkō contributes two members to the Tochigi Prefectural Assembly. In terms of national politics, the town is part of <a href="Tochigi%202nd%20district">Tochigi 2nd district</a> of the <a href="House%20of%20Representatives%20of%20Japan">lower house</a> of the <a href="Diet%20of%20Japan">Diet of Japan</a>.
Economy.
Nikkō is heavily dependent on tourism to its historical and scenic sites and <a href="onsen">hot spring resorts</a>. Hydroelectric power production, food processing, and the non-ferrous metals industry are also important components of the economy.
Education.
Nikko has 23 public <a href="primary%20school">primary school</a>s, 12 public <a href="middle%20school">middle school</a>s and three combined public primary/midde schools operated by the city government. The city has three public <a href="high%20school">high school</a>s operated by the Tochigi Prefectural Board of Education. The prefecture also operates one special education school for the handicapped.

Sports.
Nikkō is the home city to the <a href="Nikk%C5%8D%20Ice%20Bucks">Nikkō Ice Bucks</a> in the <a href="Asia%20League%20Ice%20Hockey">Asia League Ice Hockey</a>. <a href="Nikk%C5%8D%20Kirifuri%20Ice%20Arena">Nikkō Kirifuri Ice Arena</a> hosted the Women's <a href="Ice%20Hockey%20World%20Championships">Ice Hockey World Championships</a> (Division I) in April 2007.
There is also a <a href="speed%20skating">speed skating</a> oval.
